article:
'Soil microbiology' is the study of organisms in soil, their functions, and how
they affect soil properties. It is believed that between two and four billion
years ago, the first ancient bacteria and microorganisms came about in Earth's
primitive seas. These bacteria could fix nitrogen, in time multiplied and as a
result released oxygen into the atmosphere. This release of oxygen led to more
advanced microorganisms. Microorganisms in soil are important because they
affect the structure and fertility of different soils. Soil microorganisms can
be classified as bacteria, actinomycetes, fungi, algae, and protozoa. Each of
these groups has different characteristics that define the organisms and
different functions in the soil it lives in. Rao,
Subba. Soil Microbiology. Fourth ed. Enfield: Science Publishers, 1999.
Print.
